projecttitle: Misicuni Renewable Energy Hydroelectric Project
project_descrip: Short: MISICUNI RENEWABLE ENERGY HYDROELECTRIC PROJECT Long: The Misicuni Multipurpose Project is located in the Department of Cochabamba, and it's objective is to supply the central Cochabamba Valley with potable water, irrigation water and electric power generation for the National Interconnected System (NIS). Due to the dry weather conditions, the Cochabamba Valley has historically faced a water supply problem aggravated by the population growth in the region. On the other hand, the country needs to increase it¿s generation capacity preferably from renewable sources. The whole project comprises the construction of a 120-m high rock filled and concrete face dam, a 20km tunnel for water diversion (finalized in 2005 with the financial support form the Government of Italy), a pressurized piping system (from 3.700 to 2.700 meters above sea level) that conveys a controlled water flow from the tunnel to the power plant to be built in the Cochabamba Valley. The dam construction contract (US$85 million) has been awarded and the financing is in place. The works for the hydroelectric power plant, including complementary investments such as a substation and a transmission line, estimated in about US$114.1 million, will be financed with a loan from the IDB. This part of the program is important because it will provide energy to the NIS and will contribute to the financial and economical viability of the whole project.

projecttitle: Misicuni Renewable Energy Hydroelectric Project
project_descrip: Short: MISICUNI RENEWABLE ENERGY HYDROELECTRIC PROJECT Long: The objective of the Misicuni Multiple Project (MMP) is to supply drinking and irrigation water to the Cochabamba Valley, while generating electricity for the National Interconnected Syste,, using water from the Misicuni River watershed. The specific objective of the Misicuni Renewable Energy Hydroelectric Project (MHP), which is part of the MMP, is to add 80 MW of installed power generation capacity to the NIS and produce 217 GWh of electricity annually. The IDB will provide financing for the MHP, which will help: (i) expand the installed power generation capacity of the NIS to meet the growing need for electricity, especially during peak-demand hours, (ii) improve the energy matrix by increasing the share of renewable energy, and (iii) reduce subsidies to the sector and free up natural gas for export. The project has two components, one for the infrastructure works and the other to cover engineering, supervision, environmental and social mitigation, and other indirect costs.

projecttitle: Support to the Implementation of the National Plan for Irrigation and Drainage
project_descrip: Short: SUPPORT TO THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NATIONAL PLAN FOR IRRIGATION AND DRAINAGE Long: Support the Secretariat of Water (SENAGUA) in elaborating specific studies included in the current National Plan for Irrigation and Drainage 2019-2027 as a tool to increase the productivity of small and medium farmers, reduce poverty and decrease inequality levels in access to irrigation water, as well as to generate a sustainable use of water resources as a mechanism for climate change adaptation. The specific objectives are: (i) evaluate the condition of existing infrastructure and determine the investment requirements in evaluated systems, (ii) determine potentially suitable areas for agriculture within flood zones to establish a prioritizing program of agricultural drainage, (iii) assess the social and organizational situation of water users and adjust the corresponding management models, (iv) analyze the dynamics of agricultural production of farmers around areas influenced by the irrigation systems under study and develop strategies to increase productivity and income of small and medium farmers, (v) analyze irrigation water quality and establish strategies for water source conservation and sustainable use as a mechanism for climate change adaptation, and (vi) strengthen institutional capacities and coordination mechanisms between actors responsible of irrigation and drainage management (SENAGUA, local governments, Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock, Ministry of Environment, Water users organization).

projecttitle: Study tour of Jamaican Farmers to Dominican Republic
project_descrip: Short: STUDY TOUR OF JAMAICAN FARMERS TO DOMINICAN REPUBLIC Long: This TC-INTRA will finance the visit of three Jamaican farmers, leaders of Water Users Association and two National Irrigation Commission technical staff, to the Dominican Republic to learn the experience developed in this country in managing irrigation systems under a decentralized and sustainable scheme. The GoJ¿s policy is to promote the formation and functioning of Water User Associations (WUAs) as legal entities with farmers as members and shareholders who will have the power to govern these organizations. Responsibility for local management of water distribution, monitoring and system maintenance will be assumed eventually by the WUAs. The IDB funded projects are currently at a stage where wells are drilled and the beneficiaries are getting ready to commence the production and management of their respective schemes, albeit on a small scale until full transfer is given.The ability to garner knowledge and understanding of irrigation and management practices in the WUA context and the exchange of ideas bring benefits to both the host and visiting institutions, and can develop into working collaborations. It will also aid in building the confidence of the leaders of the WUAs, showing them what is indeed possible, it broadens experience, enhances knowledge, challenges thinking and will be stimulating. The Bank, has financed a program in the Dominican Republic (DR), with similar characteristic of the one financed in Jamaica. In both cases, the Water Users Association in Jamaica and Juntas de Irrigacion in DR, proposes the creation and strengthening of a decentralized mechanism to manage the system as a proved strategy that improves water management governance and sustainability. In the case of DR, this organizations have been playing an important role in water conflict management, are self sustainable and requires non or minimum interventions from the Government. In the case of Jamaica, three WUA have been formed and it is thought that sharing the DR experience will serve as a reference point to advance towards the sustainability of irrigation system in Jamaica.
